meaningMnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. In modern Japanese, 衣 is more often used to describe the clothes your food is wearing, i.e. the coating on tempura or the breading on deep-fried foods.
readingMnemonic:
What are clothes, really? Some people say <vocabulary>clothes</vocabulary> are the <reading>chromo</reading>somes (ころも) of your personal style — each garment carries information about your unique identity. Other people say clothes are simply the <reading>key</reading> to not being <reading>nu</reading>de (きぬ). What do you think?

Both ころも and きぬ mean "clothes," but these usages are old-fashioned. Also note that the more modern meaning of "coating" or "breading" uses only the ころも reading!
